newsitem.title: THAILAND: Thais see 1997/98 sugar cane down at 48.4 mln T.
newsitem.headline: Thais see 1997/98 sugar cane down at 48.4 mln T.

text.p: Thailand's Cane and Sugar Board on Monday forecast sugar cane output for the 1997/98 crushing season (November-May) would drop sharply to 48.4 million tonnes from an estimated 56.2 million tonnes in 1996/97, a senior board official said on Monday.
The sugar output is expected to fall to 5.02 million tonnes on a tel quel basis versus 5.82 million tonnes in the 1996/97 season, she told Reuters.
The official attributed the substantial drop to a severe dry spell which hit various parts of Thailand in April-June.
"The sugar cane in central and eastern regions were hardest hit with 14.6 percent and 18.8 percent respectively of the crops being damaged," she said.
About 13.9 percent of sugar cane in the northern area was damaged while the impact of the dry spell in the northeastern region was limited, the official said.
But the yield is expected to improve marginally in the 1997/98 season to 10.38 percent from 10.35 percent in 1996/97, she said.
With the improved rainfalls, the board will revise the forecast again in October.
"However, I doubt that the rain could help at this point. The dry spell hit the crop at a crucial state and that had already affected the quality of the cane," the official said.
"Even though the rain might raise the quantity of the sugar cane, we don't expect to see the output exceeding 50 million tonnes," she said.
